comments.body: Noob Scala question, how does this work? The pattern does not seem exhaustive, and what does `case x =>` (without any value on the right hand side of `=>`) produce?

> The pattern does not seem exhaustive

Pattern lists (`{ case pat => expr; ...}`) get two different treatments in the two kinds of lambda context. If the expected type is `T => R`, they get Î·-expanded like `x => x match {...}`, and normal exhaustiveness checking applies.

However, if the expected type is `T PartialFunction R`, exhaustiveness checking _does not_ apply, and the result gets a generated `isDefinedAt` (and compatible `applyOrElse` semantics) that returns true iff some `case` matching the argument is present. So the idiomatic way to write `catMaybes[A]: List[Option[A]] => List[A]` is `_ collect { case Some(x) => x }`.

`inside` takes a `PartialFunction`; as with `collect`, the inexhaustiveness is deliberate.

> what does `case x =>` (without any value on the right hand side of `=>`) produce?

`()`. This is usual for scalatest when you have nothing further to assert, see [`matchPattern` example](http://doc.scalatest.org/3.0.0/org/scalatest/Matchers.html#matchingAPattern).
